STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 11, 2024
Carlynn Denise Nichols
Children’s Center Wayne Co
79 W Alexandrine St,
Detroit, MI, 48201-2015
Re: License #: CB820201055
SI #: 2024SIC0001110
Dear Ms. Nichols:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility.
Due to the violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not
result in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for
each violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance
is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with
any questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to
someone immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2024C0001110SI
Special Investigation Intake Date: February 1, 2024
License #: CB820201055
Licensee Group Organization: Childrens Center Wayne County
Licensee Designee: Nicole Wells Stallworth
Chief Administrator: Carlynn DENISE Nichols
Agency Name: CHILDREN'S CENTER WAYNE CO
Agency Address: 79 W ALEXANDRINE ST
DETROIT, MI 48201-2015
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 04/24/2025
Capacity:
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Contact Purpose
Method
2/2/2024 12:14 PM Phone Entrance Conference; Special
Investigation Initiation
2/2/2024 1:33 PM Phone Interview
2/5/2024 1:26 PM Phone Interview
2/9/2024 12:00 PM Phone Interview
Follow up
2/12/2024 10:53 AM Phone Other

2/15/2024 11:00 AM Email Document Sent or Received
Email to and from
3/5/2024 2:07 PM Phone Preliminary finding
III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code Application submission.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12308
Section (1) An agency shall act on a completed and signed application.
Description
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency did not act on the family's application which was
submitted on 5/15/2023. The agency did not enroll the family with
DCWL until 12/5/2023 and the 3130 is still not completed.
Investigation Interviews:
Director 1
I spoke with Director 1 about the allegations on 2/2/2024 by
telephone. Director 1 reported this matter was first brought to her
attention by DHHS (Department of Health and Human Services)
on 1/31/2024. She reported upon obtaining information from their
agency’s licensing staff, she emailed the following response to
DHHS related to the family’s concern, which was provided to her
from the agency’s licensing supervisor:
“The report was resubmitted, and I (Licensing Supervisor) emailed
our consultant so she can be sure to look for it.
The issue with the family is:
Family signed the application in April of 2023. They did not decide
to continue with the licensing process until the end of June, as
they are not interested in fostering. The main issue was waiting on
them to provide a signed copy of the application. The application
they submitted had their names printed on the application, but no
signature. I didn’t get the actual signed copy until
November/December, and their report was completed in January.”
Director 1 reported Licensing Worker (LW) 3, who was assigned
to complete Applicant A’s and Applicant B’s license left the agency
and did not do the required work. Licensing Supervisor (LS) 2
was supposed to pick up where LW 3 left off and complete the
family’s licensure. Director 1 was not sure why LS 2 had not. LS 2
had reported completing the needed tasks/the family’s initial
licensing evaluation report in December 2023, but had to re-
submit it.
2

I advised Director 1 the Child Welfare Licensing Module (CWLM)
shows Applicant A’s and Applicant B’s licensing home evaluation
report was not showing as resubmitted. Additionally, CWLM
shows all social work contacts related to the family/work on the
license as entered on 1/31/2024. Additionally, the social work
contact shows there was an issue or delay with the applicants’
fingerprints. Given, the latter, I asked Director 1 why it would have
taken so long for the agency to alert Applicant A and Applicant B
of specific delay issues. Director 1 reported no knowledge of a
fingerprint issue. LS 2 did not report a delay in that area. Director
1 reported only knowing that there was an issue with the
applicants’ signatures on the application.
Applicant A & Applicant B
On 2/3/2024 I interviewed Applicant A and her husband, Applicant
B by telephone. I had a follow up interview with Applicant A by
telephone on 2/9/2024. The applicants reported attending a foster
home licensing orientation via Zoom with the agency on 4/26/2024
and submitting an application on 5/15/2023. They recalled LW 3
coming out to their home two or three-times, perhaps in May, June
and August of 2023. During the first visit they gave LW 3 their
paper work and LW 3 completed a tour of their house. LW 3
pointed out an issue with their steps/stairs, a light and exposed
wiring, and told them they needed to correct those things. LW 3
came to their home in August 2023, and they had completed the
home repair matters LW 3 had pointed out to them from their
earlier home visit. LW 3 gave them new paper work to complete, a
large questionnaire. Applicant A said due to the size/volume of
that paper work, she ended up dropping it off at the agency.
Applicant A also dropped it off because LW 3 was not answering
their phone calls, coming to pick the package up, or responding to
their messages inquiring about the status of their license.
Because of those things, they felt LW 3 was not doing her job.
Applicant A reported on or about 10/15/2023, LW 3 said LW 3 was
writing up their licensing study report. In November of 2023, they
contacted Licensing Supervisor (LS )2. LS 2 told them LW 3 left
the agency and LS 2 would now handle the licensing of their
home. LS 2 advised to give her two weeks to examine everything.
Applicant A called LS 2 again in December 2023 and LS 2
reported LS 2 was “reviewing the report to be sure it was all right”
before sending it to Lansing. Applicant A was not sure what LS 2
meant by making “sure it was all right”. She telephoned LS 2
approximately two weeks later, in January 2023 and LS 2 gave
the impression the report was sent to Lansing. LS 2 said the
person in Lansing who reviews the report and processes the
3

license had been out of the office so, LS 2 was going to follow up
with that person via email.
Applicant A and Applicant B reported their last contact with the
agency was on 1/23/2024 and they are still waiting to be licensed.
They reported going for their fingerprints in July 2023; and denied
any knowledge of there being an issue related to their finger
prints. LW 3, never phoned or texted them about a problem with
their finger prints. Other than LS 2 reporting that the fingerprint
result may not have come back yet, LS 2 did not report a problem
with those documents either. Nor did either agency staff report
that a matter with their fingerprints were delaying their licensure.
Applicant A admitted she and Applicant B are seeking to adopt
but she denied them ever procrastinating about moving forward
with licensure. She said the agency explained it might be easier to
adopt by going the foster care route. She reported with regards to
their licensing application, there were two applications. The first
one they received via email after their orientation with another
worker, Licensing Worker (LW) 4. With that one the agency had
typed in their names on the application; and asked them to sign
and return it. Applicant A said they scanned it and sent it back via
email. The other one was in October 2023, whereby LW 3
contacted her indicating she needed them to submit another
application. Applicant A asked LW 3 whether to sign the
application for the date in October 2023. LW 3 told them, no, to
date it for the original date of 4/26/2023, which they did. Applicant
A said LW 3, nor any other agency person communicated to them
the significance of their actual signature not being on the
application, or that a lack of it was delaying their licensure process
or progress. They were only told that their paperwork got
overlooked. Applicant A said she and Applicant B did everything
the agency asked of them promptly; and had the agency advised
them that their signature on the application was an issue they
would have handled that quickly also.
Licensing Supervisor 2
On 2/5/2024 I interviewed Licensing Supervisor (LS) 2 by
telephone. I received email information from her on 2/12/2024.
LS 2 affirmed Director 1’s reporting that LW 3 was assigned to
complete Applicant A’s and Applicant B’s licensure. LS 2 reported
there ended up being a problem with Applicant A’s and Applicant
B’s application. The applicants did not actually sign the
application. She said LW 3 reported Applicant A and Applicant B
wanted to adopt, and they were procrastinating about becoming
4

licensed. LW 3 kept going back and trying to get Applicant A’s
and Applicant B’s signature on the application. On one occasion
in July or August LW 3 made a home visit with the family but
forgot to get the application signed. Thereon, LS 2 was advising
LW 3 to obtain the signatures. LS 2 was not sure why that never
occurred until much later.
LS 2 reported since Applicant A and Applicant B had not signed
the licensing application, the agency did not enroll the family with
DCWL until much later than the May 2023 application receipt date.
She affirmed Applicant A’s and Applicant B’s reporting as to when
the couple went for their fingerprint scans. The couple returned
those documents to the agency on 8/15/2023. The fingerprints
were not processed until the agency received the family’s actual
signed application.
LS 2 reported when LW 3 left the agency on 12/1/2023, LW 3 had
completed the family’s licensing evaluation report on a template.
LS 2 cut and pasted information from that template into CWLM.
Additionally, she and another worker, LW 4 entered all the social
work contacts into CWLM. I also advised LS 2 that CWLM shows
all the social work contacts as entered on 1/31/2024. LS 2
reported that on 1/18/2024 she had cut and pasted the information
in CWLM and submitted the report, but apparently most of the
information didn’t save. LS 2 was not sure why the information
had not saved. She re-did it and also had LW 4 complete some
information again then they submitted the report to DCWL.
LS 2 denied reporting to the family the licensing report was
submitted in November 2023. She admitted it was very possible
that LW 3 did not explain to the family the need for or importance
of the signatures on the application that not having the signatures
on the application prevented the agency from moving on the
application. LS 2 was not sure why the agency/LW 3 had not told
the family the agency could not accept the application until the
application was signed.
LS 2 reported the questionnaire the family was given to complete
is a document that is not required for the family to complete. The
questionnaire is a tool which workers are supposed to use as a
guide to complete the interviews with families. LS 2 admitted
workers were never told to not give the questionnaire to families
either. That will be made clear to workers moving forward.
Document review:
CWLM case file for Applicant A and Applicant B which showed:
5

• The applicants attended orientation on 4/26/2023 and an
application was provided.
• An application dated 4/26/2023 signed by Applicant A and
Application B and indication the application was received
on 5/15/2023.
• The family was enrolled with DCWL on 12/5/2023.
• A social work contact of a 5/30/2023 telephone call to the
family to schedule a home visit for licensure and indication
that the applicants wanted to wait because they really only
wanted to adopt. Also, a subsequent telephone call from
the family on 6/30/2023 indicated they wish to proceed with
the licensing process and subsequent home visits with the
family on 7/1/2023 and 8/15/2023.
• Social work contacts indicating contact made to the family
about the application:
➢ 5/8/2023 a telephone call was made to the family
about the application not being signed, just having
the applicants’ name printed on it.
➢ 6/1/2023 email sent to show the family the
application was not signed.
➢ 8/15/2023 home visit with family, LW3 was to get
the application signed and forgot.
➢ 8/16/ 2023 and 8/22/2023 phone call about the
application signature.
➢ 9/15/2023 a text message was sent to applicant
about the application needing signatures and finger
print not processed.
➢ No social work contact showing the worker
explained the significance of the need for the actual
signature on the application and why the licensing
process and procedure could not proceed.
• Documentation the supervisor received the signed
application on 12/1/2023.
• A social work contact on 12/15/2023 that Applicant A was
provided an update on the licensing report, that the
previous licensing worker is no longer with the agency and
the supervisor is completing the report.
• A 1/18/2024 social work contact that the family was
informed the licensing report was completed by the
licensing supervisor and the decision about licensure will
be made by DCWL.
• The applicants’ foster home initial evaluation/reevaluation
report (CWL 3130) was submitted to DCWL on 2/20/2024.
• A final 3130 report for the applicants dated 2/22/2024 that
indicated it was completed by LW 4 and approved by LS 2.
6

• The family was issued a foster home license on 2/22/2024.
Analysis The agency accepted an unsigned application; and failed to
timely secure the family’s signed application and enroll the
applicants with DCWL. Therein the agency delayed the applicants’
application proceedings and licensure.
Conclusion Violation Established.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the agency’s
current licensing status is recommended.
April 1, 2024
______________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 11, 2024
________________________________________
Rorie Dodge-Pifer Date
Area Manager
7
